Phineas’ typical dour attitude turned towards the positive once he read the postings for the dormitory rotation at the gatehouse. There in the ‘F’s was his name listed as a move to Quanata Loft.

This was the best news he could have heard! Phineas had always wanted to board in the lofty attic where witches and wizards of great intellect, witticism and whimsy had lived before. His more scholarly interests were in the dry, language and mathematical avenues of magical theory, subjects that seemed a shoe-in to the dormitory catered to the sharpest and brightest. When he spent his younger school years in Kunok Quarters, however, Phineas considered he didn’t possess the other key characteristics seen in many residents of Quanata Loft.

He didn’t consider himself creative or artistic by any means. It was enough to write an essay, rather than poetry or fiction, nor did he fancy the visual or musical arts, unlike the collective subset of Quanata Loft geniuses. He could appreciate art but any deeper emotions meant to be conveyed by the art were lost on him. This drive to innovate made the ‘think tank’ of Quanata Loft a source of the most inventive, ambitious minds of the next generation seeking to push the boundaries of magic.

There was an individualist mindset in Quanata Loft, like a paradoxical pack of lone wolves, as many tended to be more outgoing than Phineas was. The true loaners of that dorm became eccentric in other ways, rumored to be mad and contrary to a fault. It boiled down to the lofty minded of the student body often had outlandish personalities, more personality than what Phineas had.

Still, Phineas hoped to find more of a niche for himself at Quanata Loft, compared to how he just blended into the background at Kunok Quarters. With this new optimism for his penultimate year of magical study, Phineas made his way to his transfer accommodations after his luggage was directed to the same destination.


Phineas had only passed by the dorm briefly in his past years at the Citadel, although he paused to fully take in the entrance to his new residence. The steps up to the entrance were old polished oak with brass railings. There was a faint rumble of the grinding clocktower gears, as Quanta Loft was adjacent to the Citadel’s great pentagonal-clock. Welcome banners had been put up along the twinned helix steps to the dorm’s main door, each appeared to be hand made by current residents. A variety of colors and patterns could be seen. Gathering his courage, Phineas crossed the threshold into the dormitory he felt he might have excelled at.

It was far more open than Phineas had expected. In the way that most halls of the Citadel were made as a regiment of stone rooms, blocked off by their walls, there was no further exterior wall within the high vaulted roof of the loft. Phineas could make out the highest reaches of the dorm’s commons at their dizzying height, as each level was made on a ‘skeletal’ support structure of more wood and brass. A few beams of sunlight shown down from broken patches of shingles from the roof, adding to the glow of numerous candles, solar crystals and windows. The eclectically structured loft was dotted with bookshelves of thick tomes, display cases of strange gleaming contraptions, along with artistic decor in the form of murals, statues, and kinetic banners. Each balcony of the loft already had students milling about, catching up, although most were on the lower levels gathered to organize new students and greet each other.

Once Phineas could puzzle out the chaotic structure of Quanata Loft, he realized that no bathrooms or bedrooms could be seen, indicating that the more private rooms were along the interior of the elaborate loft’s supports, thus out of sight. So he would have a quiet place to sleep, although some students could be seen hanging up hammocks along the public walkways. The outer tiers of the loft were arranged so that there would be at least two ways to look out towards other platforms of the loft. It sorta reminded Phineas of a treehouse, only if the ‘treehouse’ had been built within the entirety of a steep, spiralling Citadel roof.

There was too much to take in at once, with the echoes of other student conversation and the myriad of structures and colors. Once he got his bearings, Phineas could see some other faces he had seen from his years of schooling. Including some he considered attractive.

There was Cassandra Betteridge, a plump blonde with glasses and several quills and wands stuck in her hair. Witches of the Betteridge estate valued wit over vanity, so Cassandra cared little for her disheveled appearance compared to getting top marks. Another blonde, bubbly overachiever was Bella Lovejoy, chubby and wide hipped. She had a kind heart as sweet as the treats others got for her to thank her for her tutoring efforts, Phineas had gotten her help when they had shared a class last year and was smitten when she had eaten the entire blueberry pie he got for her in one sitting. In a crowd of people Phineas could make out the pasty white Misty Lune. A witch with albinism, a sharp intellect and flirtatious sense of humor, making jokes with a posse of friends, she was dressed in blues and lavender, enhancing her substantial chest on an otherwise thin frame. Another weighty chest was seen on May Tresfleur, one of the practicing druid Tresfleur sisters, whose clothing was woven from leaves and petals, a somewhat unusual sight for the attic dormitory but no more stand out than the rest of the colorful cast.

Catching sight of these beauties, Phineas smiled. Living in Quanata Loft this year was definitely going to be the best year of his life. He might actually strike up the nerve to get to know one of them better, rather than just watch from afar. Perhaps he would make his own worthwhile mark on the dorm, as the trappings of Quanata Loft spoke to the variety of witches, wizards and warlocks that had called this space home. However, there were more practical matters to attend to first. He had to settle into his new quarters, ready his schedule, and ease back into life at the Citadel. His fat admiration would have to take a back seat to schooling, as always.

Well, that would be an ‘average’ year at the prestigious preparatory magical academy. It turned out that Phineas would find his chubby chasing tendencies on the upswing shortly after setting foot into his new dorm…

Certainly there had to be some other access points to the Cellar for when the weather was poor? He’d only be able to find out for himself.

“How did…?” Phineas was caught off guard by the size of the door once he went down the outer steps to Wrocklehurst Cellar. What had appeared to be an average sized door was a trick of forced perspective. Few doors across the Citadel were 15 feet in height and this was one of them. In fact, Phineas noticed there was an average sized door built into the rightmost door within the oversized frame. He found it a puzzling detail. What dorm would need a door this large?

Upon properly entering the dormitory in question, it was altogether more quaint and pleasant than Phineas had expected. The dorm had an earthy, hearty sent like that of a well stocked larder. Warm colored hewn bricks framed each room and hallway as rounded alcoves that certainly brought to mind the dormitory had once been a cellar to age large barrels of mead and wine. For being underground is was very well lit from the recessed windows and greenhouse skylights overhead. Simple yet colorful cushions adorned communal sitting spaces and several potted plants hung from pots and half walls. Cheery music could be heard from somewhere, perhaps a student’s wireless.

The close connection to his least favorite subjects aside, Phineas found himself surprised at how comfortable a place Wrocklehurst Cellar appeared to look. Even his former Kunok Quarters, one of the plainest dormitories at the Citadel, carried its own image and pretentious for how student mages looked and acted. The Cellar looked rather unpretentious in that regard. He could tell from seeing the outgoing, friendly half of the Forsyth twins pass by; Faye Forsyth usually kept her hair short and dyed different colors to stand out from her twin Farah at Vinixivue Tower. For move-in day it was violet to match her eyes.

Although the more he saw as he navigated the recessed dorm, the more Phineas realized what sort of ‘problem students’ populated the dormitory. In the magical world non-human lineage was not that uncommon. Across the Citadel, each dorm carried its own share of witches, wizards and warlocks descended from the likes of vampires, trolls, elves, dwarves, tieflings and stranger things yet. Chalk up Wrocklehurst Cellar to house a disproportionate amount of those of strange lineage.

There was a boy with scaly skin and sunken black eyes, another trailing an colored aura wherever he moved and other such oddballs. Phineas, however, found himself staring at some of the girls in particular. He couldn’t help but stare, especially for ones he should have remembered seeing over the course of his previous schooling. Because there were a few that fit Phineas’ predicilitions about the female form in ways he had never dreamt up until now.

One lanky, dingy hued girl with dishwater hair looked like a kind of merrow? Mermaid? Some sort of aquatic mix given the webbing on her bare feet and hands. There was a girl who was a half-giant, currently seated but obviously taller and bigger than the average human, with some meat on her bones to go for it. A trio of chubby hobbits passed by, giggling about some sort of private joke. Then Phineas saw a girl his own age with an absolute boulder-sized belly carried in front of her that caused him to blink several times.

“Just...huh?” Phineas was beginning to feel rude. Everyone else in the dorm, especially those with more unusual features, greeted each other happily. Obviously, the Cellar brought with it a warm, accepting community of students no matter their troubles. Especially ones starting to drive Phineas’ more basic instincts wild. Looking back to an alcove where several students shared a move in treat of cupcakes, Phineas saw that the girl with the boulder belly was eating a shoe!

“You new here, buddy?”

The voice startled Phineas, as he turned on the spot wildly, catching his forehead on the wrong side of a hanging basket with a THONK to the head. “Ow!”

“Didn’t mean to startle you,” said an older boy, a resident advisor. “Nicolas Crestwell, I’m meant to get the younger years sorted but you looked to be lost. Are you alright?”

“Fine,” Phineas nursed his head. “Phineas, Fortescue. I’m here on dormitory rotation.”

“Ah, I see,” the RA smiled. “Any medical records of yours that had to be transferred from the hospital wing?”

“Pardon?” Phineas asked, confused.

“I take it you’re not a student in need of accommodations for your livelihood outside of the norm,” he winked. “Well, welcome to Wrocklehurst Cellar. Make yourself at home. Excuse me.”

Nicholas left to address a cluster of children, newly indoctrinated Citadel students as it were, a few of the young mages looking to be in the midsts of puberties Phineas had never fathomed. Growing hormonal attraction towards fat females and the mistimed exhibition of said arousal had been enough form him.

“Dormitory rotation?” Phineas found himself addressed by a new voice from another student introducing herself to him. He turned, finding that he was looking at one of the girls he had noticed earlier...

133.content:
“Me-Mel-devlian...Dungeon…?” Phineas gulped. He hadn’t expected to be placed in that dormitory. Was it some sort of mistake? Or something more sinister?

It made Phineas sound like a conspiratorial loon but sinister motives were not off the table when it came to the rumors and stereotypes of Meldevian Dungeon. Many of the students with dark personalities, gloomy outlooks, or lax views about questionable magic, congregated within the depths of the Citadel’s lower floors. It was the lowest point underground the school complex, or so it was said.

Unfortunately for Phineas, he would have to go there despite his apprehensions. His personal effects would have been delivered to the dorm for safe-keeping and he would be required to check in before he could even begin the process of trying to appeal the decision to transfer to said dungeon. If there would be boarding elsewhere in the Citadel available at that point.

Unease filling the pit of his stomach, Phineas headed down towards Meldelvian Dungeon. Usually, the lower floors echoed along the stone walls as much as any other crowded corridor of the Citadel. Approaching the lone dormitory, however, that sound gave way to eerie stillness. Suits of armor made from brackish metals and gargoyles carved from stone lined the hall to a large, gothic door. Steeling his nerves, Phineas opened the door, wincing at the creak of the hinges.

The initial view inside the dormitory certainly lived up to its name of a dungeon. Cold, slate bricks and bars built the walls and pillars of the dungeon, the ceiling arching high to honest to goodness stalactites from the ceiling. It should be a place of torture, that vibe was somehow still present, even though it had been converted into living quarters long ago during the Citadel’s founding. Leather armchairs, low light lamps and black, silvery and dull hued furnishes populated the commons with the wings leading to other rooms. Animal skins covered the otherwise bare floor.

There was an odd mist in the air, the stalactites looked hazy with this condensation surrounding them. Phineas noticed this was due to the bubbling of a large fountain set back in the commons with a strange, foul looking liquid pouring out from it into a pool.

“Excuse me.” A brusque, severe faced wizard older than Phineas brushed past him, not at all sorry. Phineas realized he had been blocking the entryway, muttering an apology to the other student that didn’t give him a secondary glance. Supposing he better get this over with he made his way into the recessed floorplan of his new dorm.

The entirety of the decor carried gothic tones. Phineas noticed shelves of odd, pickled ingredients on the walls, more taxidermy in the form of hunting and fossilized trophies. Diagrams of arcane devices and sigils that gave sinister vibes were also seen.

There were low murmurs of conversation from students gathered together around leather armchairs and sofas. The dorm wasn’t quiet but the volume subdued, with a faint hint of an echo. Many dressed in black, neutral and dark shades of hue. Phineas felt more eyeballs staring at him then there probably were...right?

It wasn’t like every evil student at the Citadel Preparatory Academy lived here. Phineas knew that was too broad of a generalization. Being the loner and closeted fat admirer that he was, he didn’t feel himself socially equipped to navigate this new environment in a dorm of gothic, counter-cultural and alternative views on the worst of magics permeated. He thought he heard a few giggles at his expense. He certainly didn’t look like the typical Meldelvian Dungeon resident.

Apprehensions aside, Phineas eventually noticed a few names and faces he could put together from the girls residing in this dorm. One, Matilda Torenza, was a curvy latina punk with wavy hair who made a name for herself causing incidents during the welcoming festivities. Then there was the full figured, rounded white Lillith Zabala, a witch with albinism and a very macabre sense of humor, who stood out even among other Meldelvian Dungeon students. He also noticed the prim, poshly dressed Olivia Montague, a bit of an elitist with blonde-brown hair and a wide, flaring bottom. She was sitting next to Teresa Mignon, the scion of a famed linage of portioners. Teresa had the thinner figure of the two but a more lavish appetite, as she chewed on teacakes where the two looked up from Phineas' passing. That didn’t account for a few other chubby girls he saw about, including one he considered had to be a tiefling on account of her colored skin, horns, and opaque eyes.

Phineas supposed he’d have a few weightier beauties to fawn over from afar. He still felt like he was in the deep of it, out of his element in the lowest dungeon of the school. He honestly felt like he was transferred to this dormitory by mistake, although fate had conspired against him at this critical point of his schooling, as he found himself thrust into meeting his ‘darkest desires’ head on…

1332.content:
"Hey! Fortescue!"

Phineas's head perked up when he heard his name called, and he looked towards the sound of the voice. He then walked over and sat down next to the person who had called him over. "Hi. Long time no see, Charity."

Tieflings were people who had one of the fiends of the lower planes somewhere on their family tree. Some were lucky and could disguise the manifestations of their hellish heritage with proper clothing, makeup, or minor illusions. Charity Brightbell was not one of those lucky tieflings. Her skin was lavender, her eyes were solid red orbs, she had a pair of dark violet horns extending out of her forehead and curving back over her skull, and she had a tail for crying out loud! Her horns naturally kept her long black hair out of her face, which made her decision to tie it back into a low ponytail an easy one. She was also rather chubby, with a sizable bosom, belly, and butt.

"So, what brings a distinguished wizard of your pedigree down here with us freaks?" Charity asked, her purple tail swishing lazily in the air behind her.

"To be honest, I don't really know," Phineas answered. "I'm trying to think about what might have prompted the move. I don't think I put the dungeons on my transfer request..."

"Well, you really saved my ass when you helped me out with Magical Theory last year. So I'll watch your back while you're down here, alright?" Charity said.

"I'd appreciate that. Thank you," Phineas said, feeling a little better about the situation he found himself in. Charity might look scary at first glance, but he knew she took her promises seriously. After a moment he looked around, realizing that Charity hadn't been sitting by herself before calling him over "So, uh, who are your friends?" he asked. Charity then proceeded to introduce the other two witches sitting near her.

One was a girl with pale skin and long black hair done up in a series of complicated braids. Her name was Mina Bloodraven, and she was a dhampyr, half-human and half-vampire. Mina appeared to be more interested in reading than in conversation, though Phineas could see her fangs when she opened her mouth to give a short introduction to herself. She dressed in an elegant red dress (Phineas thought the name of the style was gothic lolita?) and was rather petite, clearly the smallest of the three girls present. A part of Phineas couldn't help but wonder if a half-vampire could even get fat, and what that might look like.

The other girl had pointed ears, obsidian-colored skin, and long silver-white hair that marked her as one of the underground-dwelling dark elves. Phineas had learned all about the elven wars in his history classes, and even though those conflicts had been over for years the dark elves were still generally mistrusted by most who lived on the surface. Della d'Waite seemed friendly enough, though Phineas got the sense she was holding something of her true self back. The dark elf was about as chubby as Charity was, though she tended towards a more hourglass distribution of her weight with enlarged breasts and hips rather then Charity's general bigness.

In the end, Phineas's first day in Meldelvian Dungeon didn't go so badly. He actually thought he got along rather well with his unusual new dormmates. As it would turn out, these three girls, who many would consider to be monsters, would play a key role in the next major experience that Phineas had at the Citadel.

13321.content:
The next morning, classes began. As it turned out, Phineas shared his morning class, Magical Theory V, with Charity. The two walked over to the class while falling back into their old routine of bantering with each other. It was rather odd, Phineas reflected. With most other girls of Charity's size he'd be a mess, either stammering over his words or slobbering over their bodies. Somehow, he felt at ease with the tiefling girl in a way he didn't with most other people. His eyes would occasionally stop on Charity's round belly or bountiful breasts, but she either didn't notice or didn't care. He tried to keep such staring at a minimum anyway.

The two found some seats towards the back of the class, and got out everything they needed to learn. And then, Professor Natasha Nocturne walked into the classroom. The slavic witch had a severe expression, her blonde hair almost a platinum color neatly coming out from under her black pointy hat. She was also wearing a smart dark blue blazer which was tailored to her relatively petite upper half, and a black pencil skirt that covered her wide lower half. Phineas could almost literally feel Charity freeze in the seat beside him. Professor Nocturne had been their teacher for last year's magical theory class too.

If Phineas was honest with himself, he hadn't learned a whole lot from the Professor during last year's class. Sure, he'd been looking up front, but that was mainly because it was hard to look away from Professor Nocturne's wide bottom. He'd done well nonetheless because the theory of magic was honestly one of his favorite subjects in school. He was a scholar at heart, and reading about the various ideas that wizards had come up with about the nature of magic over the centuries was something he found legitimately fascinating. He picked up all the necessary lessons through bookwork alone, and thus was free to essentially zone out during class and not have to bother trying to listen to the Professor's lectures.

Charity didn't have Phineas's same intuitive grasp of the subject matter, and had at first attempted to absorb it through Professor Nocturne's lessons. Sadly, the professor's lectures were considered to be some of the most boring in the entire school (Phineas had even heard a few professors gossiping about them when they thought no student had been listening to them), and Charity tended to learn better by hearing information rather than by reading it. Thus, her first few months in Magical Theory IV had been absolutely miserable.

It had only been when she'd been at risk of flunking the class entirely that Charity had approached Phineas and asked for his help. Knowing what he did about her now, Phineas realized that she'd essentially had to swallow her pride to ask anyone for help. He had agreed to help her, of course; Phineas had asked other students for help in classes he'd had trouble with, so how could he say no to someone doing the same for him? Plus, it had been a good excuse to spend some time with a girl he found rather attractive. It had been too late in the term to raise her grade any higher than middling at best, but Charity had taken "not failing" as a win.

Now, as Phineas glanced aside at his tiefling friend, he could see some nervous sweat appear on her brow and and her wide hips shift about in her seat. The young man didn't need to be a mind reader to feel the anxiety rolling off of Charity like some kind of aura.

"You know, it won't be so bad this time," Phineas whispered in what he hoped was a reassuring tone. "I'll help translate her boringese into actual ideas for you from the start this time."

"You don't need to do that," Charity whispered back, looking strait ahead to the front of the class.

This gave Phineas pause. "You don't want my help?" he asked.

"I still haven't paid off my debt for last time," Charity responded.

Phineas felt his brain stop for a moment. "You haven't... Charity, I didn't help you last year because I was expecting some reward for it!"

Charity looked like she wanted to say something back, but before she could a loud "A-hem!" could be heard from the front of the room. Both Phineas and Charity looked up to see Professor Nocturne giving them an annoyed look. The two mumbled out apologies, and settled into their seats as the class began. The first part was, of course, an introduction where the syllabus was passed out and the general shape of the class was laid out. But once she'd gotten that out of the way, the Professor decided she still had enough time to begin the first actual lesson of the course.

This would normally be the part where Phineas would zone out and start looking around at some of his heftier classmates for the remainder of the class period, but his eyes found their way to Charity for a different reason. If he thought she'd looked anxious before, now Charity looked positively scared. She was taking notes and looking at what the professor was writing, but it looked like she was no closer to understanding what was being taught. Seeing her look so helpless solidified in Phineas's mind what he had to do.

Thankfully enough, class was eventually over. The Professor left, and the other students left, and soon it was just Phineas and Charity packing up their last few possessions. Thankfully, Phineas finished first and managed to make it over to the doorway where he blocked Charity for leaving. She stopped in front of him, staring at him. Phineas was now feeling a little nervous himself. Charity was at least 50 pounds heavier than he was. While a lot of that mass came front fat and not muscle, Phineas had no doubt that Charity could bodily shove him out of the way if she wanted to.

Thankfully, that wasn't what she did. "Move, Fortescue," she said.

"Not until you admit you need my help again," Phineas replied, standing his ground.

"I already told you I'd be fine," Charity said, not able to meet his eyes as she repeated the obvious lie.

"Do you really want to spend half a bloody semester failing tests again?" Phineas asked. That question seemed to get to Charity, and the tubby tiefling fell silent. "Look," Phineas said after a moment, "I get it. You don't like relying on anyone. But... I'm your friend, Charity. I want to help you."

Those words seemed to make something in Charity break, and she lunged forward to grab Phineas into a hug. It was rather unexpected, and for a moment Phineas felt himself frozen before he hugged her back. He could hear her take in some deep, shuddering breaths; she'd evidently been a lot more anxious about this class than Phineas had realized. The two stayed that way for some time, giving Phineas some time to appreciate just how soft the tiefling was. Finally, they broke apart, Phineas pretending not to see Charity wipe at her eyes.

"Thanks... Phineas," Charity said after composing herself. "I guess I will need your help after all. I will make it all up to you. I promise."

"You don't-" Phineas began to answer.

"But I will," Charity interrupted. "One way or another."

Realizing that this wasn't a debate that would end any time soon and that both he and Charity had other classes they needed to get to today, he decided to let the matter drop for now. As the two went their separate ways towards their different classes, Phineas began to wonder. Evidently, helping her for half a semester in magical theory last year was balanced out by her essentially being his bodyguard in the Meldelvian Dungeon this year. What was she going to do as payment for helping her out in magical theory this year?

13323.content:
As it turned out, the hardest part of adjusting to life in the Meldelvian Dungeons was needing to relearn the directions to his classes. Phineas found more than once that his feet instinctively tried to take him back towards Kunok Quarters before remembering that he wasn't living there anymore. While he had been worried about the reputation of the kind of students who called the dungeons home during the school year, it turned out that they mostly left him alone. Though that was likely due to the friends he made during that fateful first evening.

Was it too early to start calling them friends? Phineas felt fairly certain he could call Charity a friend. She was much kinder than her demonic appearance suggested she should be, though she did have a habit of teasing him. He tried to give back as good as he got, and she always acknowledged when he'd scored a point in this odd game with good-natured cheer. The one thing about her that Phineas was still getting used to was how transactional-minded she could become. In Charity's world-view, nothing came for free. If you did something nice for her, she felt obligated to return the favor no matter what. Phineas didn't complain too much, since it was this sense of obligation that led to her befriending him in the first place, but it could get a little tiring if he wanted to try doing something nice for her just because he felt like it, only to lead her to do something for him because she felt she had to.

Mina, he was a less sure about. The dhampyr was just so quiet all the time! Phineas felt like he could relate to wanting some time to oneself to destress, but he felt like he hadn't learned much more about her than he had the day they'd been introduced. She did converse with him or the others from time to time, but quite often he would find her with her nose stuck in a book. Sometimes the book was a textbook required for class, sometimes it was a romance novel, and one time Phineas was sure he saw her perusing a cookbook in the middle of class. Phineas supposed he'd just have to be patient with Mina.

And then there was Della d'Waite. The busty dark elf turned out to be one of the most competitive people that Phineas had ever met. She liked to turn the most innocuous things into games. When she learned that she'd be sharing a spellwork class with Phineas, she'd taken it upon herself to declare him a rival of sorts. Each class became a race between them to see who could master the spell or charm that the teacher had set before them each week. While Phineas supposed having someone pushing him like that had made him work harder, he definitely felt more tired after each of those classes. On the other hand, Della's competitive tendencies could also be turned to more interesting ends. One evening, Phineas had managed to turn a question about favorite foods into an impromptu eating contest between Della and Charity (Mina had abstained, not wanting to get food stains on her novel). Charity had won, though Della had said something about having a gluttony demon as a great-something-grandmother had given her opponent an unfair advantage (Phineas had also resolved to look up gluttony demons later).

The night after that particular incident, Phineas returned to the Meldelvian common room to find Charity and Della arguing.

"- not your decision to make!" Charity growled, her tail lashing behind her in with aggressive whiplike motions.

"You wouldn't say that if you saw her face!" Della replied, her fists balled in anger.

Phineas sidled up to Mina who was impassively enduring the argument while reading An Orc in Bloom. "What's going on?" Phineas asked her.

Mina looked at him, then closed the book. "Della and Tania ran into each other today," Mina said in her usual monotone.

"Ah," Phineas sighed. Tania Skyblossom was the daughter of wood elven nobility, and had carried her family's grudge against the dark elves with her into the Citadel. To call Della and Tania archenemies would not be an unfair assessment of their relationship thus far. "And what was their confrontation about?"

"Tania and some of her friends signed up for a competition of some kind," Mina said with no further explanation. There was really none necessary. Based on his knowledge about Della's competitiveness and her relationship with Tania, Phineas had a good idea about what was going on. He then tuned back into the argument again.

"You should have told us!" Charity said, her voice now much less heated. "We're happy to help if you ask us, but just making a unilateral decision without even asking our opinion is seriously not cool!"

"I... I guess..." Della murmured, before seeming to pick up steam again, "But we can't back out now! We'd be laughed at for cowardice!"

"If I may," Phineas interrupted, causing the two girls to look at him. "What exactly has Della signed us up for?"
13323.title: Delocalized Contests by Della

133233.content:
"The... the Dueling Tournament! You can't be serious!" Phineas fought to keep his breathing under control. He'd gone his whole school career without getting into a fight, and he liked that record.

"Hey, Brighteyes! Deep breaths!" Della said (Brighteyes being the nickname she chose for him, on account of Phineas's dark eye color. She was weird like that.). The dark elf waited for Phineas to calm down a little before continuing. "I admit, I may have been a little impulsive," she said (eliciting an amused snort from Charity), "But I think we've actually got a real shot at this!"

"Do we?" Charity asked, her question actually genuine rather than snarky.

"Me and Brighteyes here have been rivals in Spellwork IV for weeks now," Della confidently replied, looping her arm around Phineas's shoulder and dragging him close to her. Phineas did his best to ignore how soft the side of her chest felt. "He and I, we're always among the first to master a new curse or concept! Except for that pudding spell..."

"Yeah..." Phineas responded, looking down at the ground. Both Charity and Mina looked at the two for some explanation, but none came.

"Anyway, I know he's a little jumpy, but he's got talent!" Della said, plowing over the awkward pause in the conversation like a charging bull. "All we need to do is help him channel that talent into some proper dueling spells, and bam! Victory is ours!"

"It can't possibly be that easy," Phineas muttered.

"You'd think that! But!" Della said, letting Phineas loose and heading over to Charity, puller her close in a side-hug similar to the one she'd used on Phineas, "Cherry here is actually one of the best duelists in the school! She's learned how to do some of the somatic spell stuff with her tail! So while the enemy's looking at her hands, wondering what she's gonna do, she's hiding her whammy behind that big butt of hers!"

"Bigger than yours, skinny," Charity responded, knocking Della away from her with her hip. Phineas hoped his face wasn't as red as it felt at the talk of big butts. Thankfully, it seemed that he was being ignored as Della moved on to the last member of their little group.

"And Min-Min!" Della began, pulling Mina close to her in the same way she had Phineas and Charity. She then paused, seeming to realize something. "Um... I've never, uh, actually seen you duel before... But I'm sure you'll be great!" Phineas and Charity shot disbelieving stares at Della, while Mina continued to read her book as if they weren't even there. The dark elf let her arm drop from around Mina's shoulder and coughed.

There was an awkward silence among the four for a time, which got broken by an exasperated sigh from Charity. "Look you two," she said, speaking to Phineas and Mina. "I've known Del for a long time, and once she gets an idea like this in her head, it's hard to get it out. How about we head over to the practice fields and we can get an idea about what we need to work on. Worst comes to worst, we just won't show the day of if you're not really feeling it." Della began to protest at that, but backed off when the tubby tiefling shot her a red-eyed glare.

Deciding to save face, Della said, "That... that sounds like a good idea! Let's go practice!" Which was how the four found themselves heading towards the dueling practice grounds in one of the Citadel's many courtyards. It looked like quite a few students were taking the time to brush up on their skills. Phineas now found himself wishing that he hadn't spent those past weekends in his earlier school years avoiding going to the tournament to brush up on his studies. It would have been nice if he had a better idea about just what his new friends had roped him into. Well, he couldn't change the past; in the present, he'd see just how terrible he was at dueling.

134.content:
No sort of divinatory magic, astrological sign, horoscope, or winning lottery ticket could have indicated how lucky Phineas Fortescue was to board at Vinixivue Tower given this year’s dormitory rotation results. It was quite the unexpected surprise for the lad going into his penultimate year of magic studies.

Vinixive Tower was hard to miss. When it came to the skyline of the Citadel Preparatory Academy for Rites & Sorcery, no tower was taller. Indeed, nor was any more ostentatious. A shining jewel of opulence at the wizarding school, a golden globe laced with rare magical minerals, its brilliant stained glass windows seemed to declare to the magical world at large that the best, brightest, bravest and boldest of the next magical generation earned their stripes here.

That is, if you took credence of all of the Tower’s grandiose image at face value. Phineas knew of a few noted noble families whose progeny called Vinixivue Tower home. House Fortescue was a long standing, storied family of similar prestige. Not the most blue-blooded or richest, when it came to politics within the great magical clans, but a populous house of many witches and wizards with notable accomplishments across all avenues of magic life. Such was the breadth of the family’s past that none of the Fortescues had a ‘default’ dormitory to find lodging at during their years at the Citadel. That he hadn’t landed at Vinixivue earlier was no demerit.

In fact, Phineas was finding the ornate staircase up to the tower to be far too posh. Was there a word for that he hadn’t used already regarding Vinixivue Tower? The marble laden steps were fenced by a golden bannister with silver-wrought ironwork as ornate as the gem encrusted stained glass windows encircling the tower. This brought Phineas to the landing, just in time to see a golden glass cage perpendicular to the dormitory entrance descend down the spiral steps, held up by nothing by skyhooks.

“Oh,” Phineas sighed. He had missed seeing the elevator. Even the other outlying dormitories by height or depth didn’t have such options, although he supposed Vinixivue Tower was really high up in the Citadel, rivalled only by Quanata Loft. Passing through the old oak doors, Phineas himself in the dormitory he had least expected he would ever stay at.

The interior of the Tower’s commons were quite palatial. High vaulted ceilings supported by elegantly sculpted columns showed the painted, slightly moving ceiling frescos over a posh, gilded accommodations. Fine furniture and velvety curtains separated rooms were elite snobs rubbed elbows and wide-eyed newcomer kid mages marveled at the gleaming trophies and view over the Citadel. Phineas initially felt small next to these hubristic rich kids, big name partiers and the ambitious, boundary looking sorts seeking to woo prestige worthy of their magical might by name, guile or charm.

He almost felt underdressed, seeing as most others were moving in with their finest clothes. Which seemed impractical to Phineas but then he had never thought he’d wind up in a dorm where image was everything. It sure looked nice. And, as his mind started to wander and some warmth entered his nether regions, there were a smattering of fine, plush lovelies he was ogling as much as others would ogle exquisite art.

One of his long time, from a distance crushes had been Margot Francois, of a very ancient noble family. Thick thighed since their intermediate school years, the thunder-thighed honey was far weighty than most of the campus’ prettiest girls tended to be although no less beautiful for her curves. Her perfectly coiffed, blonde ringlets framed her rounding face, as her plumping middle sat in her silken dress, her great thighs spilling out from under the hem to her white stockings. Upon hearing a chorus of laughter, Phineas noticed another girl within a clique of friends. Chelsea Morgana turned a lot of heads on campus and she did not disappoint the image of seeing her in person. A witch with short, platinum blonde hair, she had the largest pair of breasts on campus. They almost looked comical inside her pink sweater, although several eyes followed Phineas’ stare as her audience watched them bounce to her mirthful laughter from a joke, fitting her affectionately-derogatory nickname of 'Chesty' Morgana.

Starting to feel hot under the collar, Phineas supposed he better get his affairs in order. Even though he had an unerring knack for noticing overweight girls at the school, he wasn’t sure about his chances with girls that had been popular with the student body for most of their lives at the Citadel. Yet maybe arriving at Vinixivue Tower was the opportunity for something new? Perhaps he might even find his own boldness. Nevertheless, living at Vinixivue Tower was certainly going to be different!
134.title: Vinixivue Tower

choices: Margot Francios, Thunder-Thighed Scion of French Nobility
Tania Skyblossom, Hourglass-Shaped Elven Princess
Bolka Goldhammer, Big-Bellied Daughter of a Dwarven Clan Chief
1344.content:
While he wasn't drawing too many stares yet, Phineas decided he might make a better impression on his new dormmates if he dressed up a little. So, he headed of to the boy's dorms, found the room that had his & some other boy's name written on the door, and headed inside to unpack.

Phineas whistled as he looked around. The room was actually a fair bit bigger than the accommodations he'd had back in Kunok Quarters, and the four-poster beds with their immaculate sheets looked comfier than the bed he'd slept on for the first years of his schooling. It looked like he was moving up in the world. He was about to start hanging up his clothes when he looked at his bed again. Sitting atop one of the pillows was a letter that had his name on it. Curious, Phineas picked the letter up and opened it.

The message contained within the writing was rather strange. Evidently, the writer had pulled some strings to have him moved here from Kunok Quarters, and proposed a partnership of sorts. The writer would help Phineas move more easily in the elite social circles of Vinixvue Tower, in return for Phineas supporting them with a project of their own. Annoyingly, the writer hadn't really included any details about what the project was and what kind of support he'd be expected to provide. The whole thing seemed rather suspicious in Phineas's view.

He was tempted to throw the letter away and forget he'd even seen it, but he decided to read through to the end. The big shock was when he saw the signature of the person who had written the message. Why the heck would a witch as influential as the writer think Phineas had anything to offer them? Why would they even have noticed him in the first place? Phineas would admit he thought that the person in question did have some rather alluring curves, but he thought he'd been careful about not staring too much.

In the end, Phineas knew he couldn't really turn the writer of the letter down. He'd heard plenty of rumors of what had happened to those who disregarded the whims of Vinixvue's most influential mages. Getting kicked out of the tower would be the least of his worries; he'd seen some students' lives become absolutely miserable. Phineas tried to suppress a groan; he'd not even been here one day, and already he was caught in the middle of the cutthroat political world of the Citadel's most illustrious dorm. Why couldn't he have gone to Quanata Loft?

His train of thought was derailed when he heard someone knock on the door to his room. "It's open," Phineas said, expecting that it would be his roommate coming to get their side of the room set up. Thus, it was a surprise that the voice he heard spoke behind him was feminine rather than masculine.

"I see you read my letter," the voice said.

Phineas spun around to see the form of the weighty witch who had gotten him into this mess.
1344.title: Friends in High Places

choices: Margot wants Phineas's aid in taking down a rival of hers.
Margot is working on a school project that Phineas can help with.
Margot is trying to invent a new spell, and wants Phineas's input.
Margot seeks companionship and the Fortescues are a respectable name.
13441.content:
Phineas gulped as he turned around to face the person who'd addressed him. He'd had dreams that had started out similar to this situation. He just hoped he'd be able to not entirely make a fool out of himself.

Margot Francois was a girl that Phineas had been crushing on for a long time. It wasn't just her curves, though they were rather enticing (especially in the dress she was wearing right now). There was no shortage of curvy girls in the Citadel. After he had figured out what he found attractive in a potential girlfriend, Phineas had thought that was all there was to it. But he'd come to realize that wasn't the whole story.

What attracted Phineas to Margot over other girls in her weight class was her confidence. He'd been moving in the background for a long time, and Phineas had come to realize that most of the weightier women on campus hated their size. To them, it was an indication of weak willpower, a badge of shame that needed to be hid. There were others who were simply indifferent to their size, treating it like it was their hair color or height, something not to be worried about. But Margot Francois owned her body, her immensity, and reveled in it. Whether she was intimidating small students or speaking in public, Margot made sure that you couldn't ignore her. Sometimes, Phineas wished he could put himself out there the way Margot did.

Phineas then realized that while he had been thinking, his eyes had been looking at Margot's luscious legs. He quickly moved them up to the girl's eyes. There was a small smirk on her face, but she didn't address the faux pas. Phineas wondered if it might not have been better if she did.

"So? What do you think of your new accommodations, Mr. Fortescue?" Margot asked. Though her family was French, Margot spoke English without a hint of an accent, a testament to how thoroughly she had mastered the language.

"It's... it's good. Thank you," Phineas said, trying to keep calm. "So... uh... what can I do for you, Miss Francois?"

Margot's smile widened. "I'm so glad you asked that."
13441.title: The Indomitable Margot Francois

choices: Tania wants to better understand humans outside of Vinixvue Tower.
Tania needs help understanding human magical theories.
Tania needs someone to smuggle more tasty treats into the Citadel.
Tania believes Phineas is the champion in an old faerie prophecy.
13442.content:
Phineas's world seemed to stop for a moment when he heard the high-pitched, airy voice behind him. There was no way that she'd noticed him, was there? But then he turned around, and it was indeed Tania Skyblossom there.

Tania was rather famous for being the first wood elven princess to attend the Citadel. For centuries, the elven kingdom had kept itself isolated from the rest of the world. But after its wars against the dark elves, the wood elves had emerged to try and create closer ties to some of the human nations. One of the ways they attempted to foster this relationship was to send one of the princesses of the wood elf kingdom to the most premiere human magic school in the world.

Said Princess's face was bright and cheery, with big eyes the color of the afternoon sky. Her cherry blossom-pink hair fell down from her head in waves, kept out of her face by an expertly-crafted circlet. It was out of the pink cascade that Tania's pointed ears, the most obvious indicators of her heritage, poked out. From the neck up, Tania looked like the perfect elven princess.

When one went down... well. Tania had started out her schooling with the lithe frame that most elves were known for, but years upon years of human food had greatly added onto it. Added in interesting ways, Phineas thought; she had a rather sizable chest, a wide set of hips, and a waist that was narrower then both, though it couldn't be called narrow in a literal sense. Tania's hourglass shape was usually on display too, since she favored elven clothing which tended to be skimpier then the styles favored by humans.

"What's wrong? Pixie got your tongue?" Tania asked with a giggle, making Phineas realize he'd been staring.

"Uh, no. I mean, I read your letter. I'm just wondering what I did for such kindness," Phineas responded. Maybe he was laying it on a little thick, but he figured when dealing with royalty that too much respect was better than too little.

"I've been observing you for a while, actually," Tania said, smiling.

"You... have?" Phineas asked, feeling a sinking pit in his stomach.

"Yes, and I have a problem I think you can help me with," Tania answered.
13442.title: Princess Tania Skyblossom

choices: "Of course not. I was able to get quite a few newcomers moved up here!"
"Not quite. There are a few others I think we can count on."
"Yes, just us two."
"Actually, we already have some opposition against us."
13443.content:
After he turned around, it took Phineas a moment to reorient himself to look down at the person who had written to him. Bolka Goldhammer was a dwarf, standing at around four-and-a-half feet tall. She had hair the color of a cardinal's feathers, done up in a series of elaborate braids, and slate-grey eyes. Her frame was stocky and solid, as most dwarves tended to have. Hers was rather softer than the typical dwarf's was though, and she sported a potbelly that she didn't really bother to hide.

"I did," Phineas said in response to Bolka's statement. "What can I do for you, Miss Goldhammer?"

"Drop the 'Miss Goldhammer' crap, Phineas. My name's Bolka. Use it," Bolka said, somewhat irritably.

"Ah, of course. What do you need, Bolka?" Phineas asked, trying to puzzle the answer out for himself before Bolka answered. From what he recalled in his history classes, the dwarves were split up into a number of clans that vied for money and territory. The Goldhammer Clan was obviously one of the most successful, since Bolka had been considered eligible for Vinixvue Tower.

"You might not know this, but I wasn't always living up here in the sky," Bolka explained. Phineas nodded; he now remembered that at one point, she'd lived in the Meldelvian Dungeon. "I got moved up here last year, and it's been miserable. All the people up her have their clans... er, cliques, would be a better word, I guess? Well, there's not a lot of room for a newcomer."

"So... you need allies, then?" Phineas asked.

"Smart lad. Got it in one!" Bolka said, smiling. "It won't be so bad with us looking out for each other."

"Just us two?" Phineas asked, wondering if this was the start of something wonderful or something terrible. Probably both at the same time, considering his luck.

Bolka shot Phineas an odd look, but then responded to his question.
13443.title: Boistrous Bolka Goldhammer

choices: Phineas is assigned to the girl dorms by accident.
He's been made a residential advisor to help student problems.
He's been selected as a rep for KQ in the Dormitory Prestige Grand Prix.
Everyone recognizes Phineas in a strange fashion with his secret well known.
135.content:
Phineas sighed. "Figures I would be the one student transferred back to their regular dorm."

The result that he was stuck at Kunok Quarters again was a mild annoyance. He must have missed the cutoff date to apply for the dormitory transfer, much as he had last year. Only then it had been family pressuring him to better his prospects. This time Phineas had actually considered he might do with a change. There were wild, elaborate stories about how some of the students lived at the Citadel's other dormitories, quite the change of pace to an otherwise unremarkable wizard with a fat fetish.

That wasn't a slight against staying at Kunok Quarters by any means. They were perfectly fine dorms, although a tad 'average' compared to the eclectic mix of types in the premier magical academy. That was according to the dorm's detractors, although those who flocked to Kunok Quarters weren't picked for udders.

Indeed, the community fostered at the long building of student housing suites saw its orderly design and basic fulfillment of needs as a strength. The Citadel Academy was a boarding school, after all, and with education as diverse and chaotic as the magical arts could get, there was something to be said for having the quiet comforts of home to retire to after a day of classes. Other dorms claimed to have the cleverest, the slyest, the most accommodating, or the boldest of their generation. At Kunok Quarters age, background, disposition towards magic and expertise hardly mattered. Your magic proved how could of a witch or wizard you were, so the students of the dorm banded together with neighborly friendships, at the very least as positive acquaintances, rather than relationships built solely on their dormitory's image.

The wings of the building that housed Kunok Quarters, stretched between the main assembly courtyard the Citadel's array of temples to various deities of magic, were patterned over a familiar template framed in stone and timber. Student bedrooms were often shared with private commons for dorm mates, with public gathering halls in-between. Most floors had balcony access on one side. The furnishings were plain, functional and meant to be a solid foundation as students focused on their magical studies. Kunok Quarters was strategically located as close tot eh center of the Citadel campus as possible, making it easy to reach any class building and other hotspots in the complex. It didn't take long to walk down to Challenge Lake, for example, or to access the Great Hall, Gatehouse, Hospital Wing or Mail Office.

As Phineas approached the dorm he could hear excited conversation, the crackle of magical sparks or firecrackers, and music played on those talented with instruments. The dormitory was at its liveliest during holidays and special events, such as competitors between the dorms. Welcoming day was no exception. He offered himself a small smile knowing that he'd be returning to a well worn niche at the school. Not the most stupendous but perfectly acceptable.

It was finishing his checking in during his return to Kunok Quarters, however, that showed Phineas that his year was going to decidedly be unlike his previous years of schooling at the Citadel.
135.title: Back to Kunok Quarters

choices: There's always something to eat at the feast.
Taking in the demos and performances of the pavilion tents.
Phineas unexpectedly becomes privy to some illicit activities.
He stumbles into a situation he would rather not be in.
The festival passes as a blur. The morning after, however, is more complicated.
14.content:
There was no crazier time at the Citadel Preparatory Academy for Rite & Sorcery than the Welcoming Festival. It introduced students to the wonders of life at the ancient magical fortress. In many ways it was the last chance for fun before the serious approach to studies was enforced by the teaching staff.

All in all the Welcoming Festival was quite compact. It lasted from the time students arrived on the locomotive to an official cutoff point of about 10 pm (22 hrs) although several students had their own ideas for festivities that could easily last until midnight.

The Citadel did not disappoint during a party. There was a grand feast, the first big meal of the year. There were numerous displays and marvels, from swarms of trained bats to choirs of nymphs, performing ghosts, dancing skeletons and other such supernatural entourages. In the center pavilion there would be tents with demonstrations as to the varied courses in magic the Citadel offered. Student leaders also had booths for various student organizations and clubs. New students were typically lead into icebreaker games at whichever of the five dormitories they had been assigned. The festivities were closed off by a spectacular fireworks show at 22 hrs.

Although the more rambunctious students had their own plans for the Welcoming Festival, activities that were never effectively quashed. Smuggling in booze was quite common, the magical world having several strange and potent brews. Those longing in their freedoms would sneak into unauthorized areas or plan elaborate pranks against a disliked teacher or student. Some would try to find a private area for impromptu make out sessions.

All Phineas Fortescue knew was that the Welcoming Festival was loud. It wasn't a celebration one could sit out (he'd tried before) as the noise and atmosphere from the event permeated the whole Citadel. Anyone hoping for a slow progression into academy life or someone as introverted as Phineas wasn't going to find much of interest in the various distractions of the Welcoming Festival. At its worst, all the hullabaloo was just annoying to experience.

Going into his penultimate year at the Citadel, however, Phineas had finally settled on the notion of not trying to fight the festivities. True, the Welcoming Festival was not his cup of tea but this was one of his last festivals. Perhaps this outlook was a sign that Phineas was finally coming out of his shell.

So what does Phineas try next?
14.title: The Welcoming Festival

choices: Student Government
The Spellball Team
The Magical Baking Club
142.content:
Phineas spent some time wandering about the pavilion, taking in the sights. It was more crowded and noisy than he was really comfortable with, but he reminded himself that he was going to try and be a little more social this year. So he spent some time looking at the demos and striking up conversations with some of his fellow students. Nothing went beyond the surface-level niceties, but it was still progress!

Then, Phineas decided to try some of the games. He actually did fairly well at one of the target-shooting stalls where participants fired colored lights out of a provided wand. He was awarded with a few tickets that he was told he could redeem at one of the other tents for various prizes. He didn't fare so well at a quiz game, though the chubby witch who won it hadn't really had any competition anyway. He played a few more games in this way, ending up with a respectable number of tickets.

But games weren't the real reason he'd come this way. One corner of the pavilion had been set aside for the various student-run clubs to recruit new members, and it was proving to be one of the busiest places in the festival. Phineas recalled avoiding this part of the festival in his earlier years for precisely that reason; so many voices all chattering at once were likely to give him a headache. Still, he had to persevere. So he steeled himself, and started looking around.

The student government booth was the biggest booth around, and was covered in posters extolling the value of the organization. Well, not entirely, seeing as there were going to be student council elections fairly soon, which meant that many of the posters were extolling the values of the various candidates for President, Vice-President, Secretary, and Treasurer. It seemed like a lot of work to Phineas, but being a part of student government might be fun.

The other big booth belonged to the Spellball team. Phineas knew the sport was a fairly popular one among his peers, though he wasn't exactly a big sports fan himself. If he remembered correctly, the most important rule of spellball was that the players weren't actually allowed to physically touch the ball with their bodies. He'd watched spellball games a few times, and dizzying array of different magics that players used during play could get confusing. Still, he might end up having some talent, and being a sports star might help if he wanted to try getting a girlfriend.

Beyond those two were booths for many other clubs. It seemed like there was a club for everything at the Citadel. There was a dueling club, a chess club, a theater club, even a club devoted to magical baking. But while some students seemed to be able to juggle two or three clubs and their grades simultaneously, Phineas knew that he wasn't one of those students. No, he was going to join one club so that he'd be able to keep up with everything. It took him some time to work through which organization he wanted to join, but before the end of the night he made his choice about which organization he wanted to join.
142.title: Fun and Games and Student Organizations

choices: Play it cool, Phineas, and your wildest dreams will remain true.
Deflect the question while trying to tease out details of last night.
Bolt for the door!
Hell hath no fury like four witches that catch you in a lie.
145.content:
Phineas slowly felt his mind stir. His eyes were closed as he was splayed out on the bed. It was a comfortable, cozy feeling, rising out of sleep without a care in the world. His dreams were a slurry that he couldn't decipher with a half awake mind but something had felt good about them. He shifted, his arms reaching out into the cushions. The surface was warm and fleshy under the cloth, jiggling from his touch, and he gave it a squeeze.

"Mhmmm..." a pleasurable moan came from the other occupant of the bed.

Adrenaline jolted Phineas awake as his eyes shot open.

This wasn't his room. This wasn't his bed! He tilted his head furtively, looking from side to side. Under the sheets two massive forms sandwiched him in the middle of the bed. He heard snoring. To his right was the rising stomach of a rather fat girl. Phineas was stunned, feeling himself grow hot and it wasn't from the covers. He'd dreamed about putting forward the effort to talk to one of the fat, weighty women of his affections and here he was, impossibly waking beside one. He had to pinch himself to see if he was still dreaming.

Another low moan of ecstasy escaped from his left side bedmate. He had forgotten where his hand had strayed.

Phineas was waking up in bed next to two fat beauties!

"Morning'," came the purr from his left. Phineas was face to face with a round, freckled face framed by auburn hair and adorned with sparkling green eyes. A girl about his age smiled at him, peeling herself free from the bedsheets.

The shock in face continued as Phineas found his eyes looking down the length of her horizontal body. While her face was round not too much of her was out of proportion...until he saw her wide, fat thighs spilling out of her white nightdress, each thigh as thick as his waist. They were as freckled as her face.

She grinned, revealing a slight gap in her teeth. "Gosh, you look more frightened than pixie about to be eaten by a bugbear."

"Uh-h-h-h..."

Suddenly, even though this was exactly where Phineas wanted to be he felt very uncomfortable. He backed up, wanting to put more appropriate distance between him and the thick thighed godiva in the bed, forgetting about the other occupant that had him trapped on the mattress.

The large bellied behemoth snorted awake. "Huh? That you Siv?"

"No silly," said the freckled, leg heavy girl Phineas had squeezed in his sleep, presumably Siv. "It's our new friend, Maeve, he's all flustered."

"The cutie?" Maeve turned over, catching Phineas off guard. Maeve had big lips, blue eyes and a small mole just off her chin, framed by sandy brown hair. She probably had fifty or so pounds on Siv, mostly resting in her middle. "You're still here! Last night was so much fun."

"L-Last N-Night??"

Phineas had completely blacked out about last night. He recalled getting off the train upon arrival at the Citadel. The welcoming festivities had been underway...but he couldn't remember anything else. What was he doing in a bed shared by two other, if very attractive, weighty girls? Suddenly Phineas realized himself, finding that he thankfully had slept in his uniform but it was in disarray.

"Come here," Maeve continued, rolling over with an arm outstretched to hug Phineas.

Whatever destiny had gotten Phineas into this situation failed him now that he was back to his senses as he tried to scramble back, hoisting himself upright.

"Don't crush him, Maeve," Siv chided, "you're scaring him."

"I'm t-terribly sorry," Phineas tried to begin, mind racing as he tried to make sense of the whole affair. Caught off balance, both mentally and physically, he felt himself teeter as he tried to step over Siv and found himself instead falling over her and off the bed, the floor rushing up to meet him.

At least the landing was soft. Not only from the carpet, as Phineas had landed face first into a perfectly pliable, peach shaped bum of someone passed out on the floor.

Three?!

"I'm up!" came a singsongy voice that soon faltered. "Ooo dear, I've had too much to drink."

Phineas scrambled up. The broad, lovely shaped bum shifted to reveal the blonde that blinked his direction. "Who are you again?"

Siv giggled from the bed, before helping Phineas sit up with a pair of strong yet soft hands. "Calliope, honestly, you were the first to meet him!"

"Ooh ho ho~," Calliope turned, leaning in far too close as Phineas realized she was half dressed in the Citadel's uniform and a pair of pale yellow tights. Her skin was bronze and her teeth gleaming white. Her voice carried that musical quality again. "The Phinery, right? Phin-phin."

"Phin-phin?" Phineas mouthed, worriedly.

"Siv, you've had too much time to cuddle with him," the hefty Maeve complained, dressed in a red bathrobe now that she emerged from the sheets.

"Cuddle?" Phineas felt the blood drain from his face as every impossible fantasy he'd had in his years of coming to this school went off in his head.

He couldn't help it that the draining blood decided to enter a certain other body part.

"Oh my," Calliope, the bottom heavy blonde, put a hand to her lips as she looked down. Phineas followed suit and quickly flung his hands to cover his arousal.

There was a knock at the bedroom door. "Ladies, aren't you up yet? Gods, I had way too much to eat last night."

A fourth girl entered the room. She had long black hair trailing down her back and sultry, heavily makeup'd eyes. Unlike the rest she was dressed but not in the school uniform. Her blouse was loose and her slacks unbuttoned for good reason. Her hands cradled a burgeoning potbelly from her otherwise slender frame. "I can't go to classes looking like..." She caught sight of Phineas, staring.

"Gird?" Said Siv, the playfulness in her voice dropping into concern. "Oh no, class! I have a full morning of druid rituals!" The freckled, thick-thighed honey jumped out of bed.

"Boo!" said Maeve, as her stomach rumbled. "Please tell me the morning back breakfast will be as good as the feast."

"I'm due back for my apprenticeship," said Calliope, groaning, "but last night was so much fun."

Gird, the black haired newcomer, stifled a belch. "Gotta admit, Fortescue, I always thought you were too much of a dud." She flashed him a brief smile before turning serious. "But I think it's best if you don't say anything more about what all happened yesterday.

"Uh, sure," Phineas said. What in the hells had happened yesterday? He couldn't have loose lips about events he couldn't personally remember.

In the midst of the three large ladies and the potbelly vixen getting themselves ready for the first lessons back at the Citadel, Siv paused as she looked at Phineas's bewildered confusion. "Wait. Do you not remember what happened last night?"

Phineas froze.
145.title: Bewildering Waking

choices: Maeve, the hearty massive cleric.
Siv, the romantic thunder-thighed druid
Callipoe, the bubble-headed bottom-heavy bard.
Gird, the skinny but pot-bellied summoner.
Another wrinkle from last night, as a different girl recognizes Phineas.
1452.content:
At Siv's question, all four of the girls stared directly at Phineas. This unbelievable dream would turn into a nightmare if Phineas admitted he couldn't really remember how he had wound up sharing a bed with two of them.

"Last night?" Phineas replied, thinking fast. "Of course. Well, mostly, I've got a bit of a headache actually."

"You poor thing," Siv said, feeling his forehead, as Phineas stared into her eyes to avoid looking down at the heft of her thighs as she knelt beside him. "The drinks were my and Gird's idea, I'm sure we're all a little hungover."

"The drinks, yeah," Phineas caught on, "I'm honestly not much of a drinker." Truthfully, Phineas had never had more than the occasional wine if at a fancy meal, he had never fancied the taste of alcohol.

"You're all weak-livered!" Maeve chuckled, heaving herself up from the bed. "Still, not unexpected when you decide to cross mugs with a cleric of the Divine Harvester."

Divine Harvester? Phineas wasn't as versed on his religions, although several divine domains had their respective temples about the Citadel for the purposes of instructing their followers. He remembered there was a goddess of food and drink but the name escaped him.

"And to think that prank of yours almost backfired," Calliope said. "Has anyone seen my flute?"

"Prank?" a new mystery caught Phineas off guard.

"Here," Gird said, waving her hand as a magical portal briefly appeared in the air as a silvery flute passed out of it, as she handed it to Calliope.

"Thanks," Calliope smiled. "Although I'm glad to have met you, Phinny, you've got a raw but lovely tenor voice that could do with some training."

"Th-thanks," Phineas said. He had been singing, too?? Phineas could understand music theory well enough, he had never fostered the talent.

"Although sneaking up to the south tower roof was a better spot to view the fireworks from," Siv said.

"Alright girls, enough chit-chat," Gird said. With a clap of her hands a crackle of eldritch fire appeared above them, with a winged impish quasit appearing in the flames. "Ready my Enchanting Workbench," she instructed, and the quasit disappeared. She prodded her stomach. "This belly is a little more problematic, do we have any bloat-away potion?"

"There might be some in the bathroom," Calliope said. "Gosh, I have to tune my lute today too."

Maeve heaved a heavy sigh. "And there's morning rituals for me."

That's right, today was the first day of classes at the Citadel. Phineas felt almost forgotten as the girls hurried about the business. "So, the four of you are roommates, right?"

"Of course," Siv said, opening the window. With a soft gesture she encouraged the vines outside on the castle walls to blossom into small flowers.

"It's just, uh, surprising I guess given your various magical aptitudes." Through observation and brief explanation, Phineas learned that the four students focused on the clerical, druidic, bardic and summoning branches of magic. That is to say, Maeve channeled her faith with her goddess into divine miracles; Siv was greatly attuned to the natural world with reverence; Calliope practiced how magic was much like music, it had patterns and improvisation; and Gird focused on the aspects of reality, summoning verges and aid from other realms of magic.

"What's your expertise, Phinny?" Calliope asked.

"Nothing in particular, I guess I'm more scholarly," he admitted.

"Really? Well, maybe we can meet up for some study groups, I'm quite lousy on my history--" Calliope trailed off, the situation dawning on her. "Wait, you're still here!"

"Yeah," and then the same concern dawned on Phineas. "It's been great meeting you all, but how do I get out of here unnoticed?"

The four student witches paused. "We didn't actually think of that," Maeve said.

"Actually, where are we?" Phineas asked.

"This is Kunok Quarters," Siv said.

Phineas let out a whistle. "*phew*, that simplifies matters I guess. I belong in the boys' dorms."

Several ideas for how to help Phineas leave unnoticed came up, from having him crawl along the window ledge, turn him invisible, turn him into a frog or such to smuggle him out, use a broom, all ideas quickly shot down as they grew more and more ludicrous.

"How good are you with tight spaces," Gird asked.

"I'm not claustrophobic, if that's what you're asking," Phineas said.

"Come with me, you have to promise me you won't say anything about this," Gird said.

"And promise you'll stay in touch with us!" Maeve said. Phineas had managed to skate out of there with his neck intact, fancied by each of the girls as much as he was intrigued by them, yet still horribly confused as to how he got into this situation.

Gird led him into the girl's shared living room, crossing to a curtained closet. "I've got a traveling trunk," she said, parting the curtain to reveal a large box chest. "It's how we've been sneaking things inside the Citadel."

"Ah, right," Phineas mouthed."

"I've got another one that's still housed in receiving luggage by the gatehouse," Gird explained, "so that gets you outside the doors where you'll draw less attention. That sound okay."

"Sure, um, thanks again," Phineas said. Compared to how he felt this morning, lying down in a magical trunk was the least awkward and unusual.

"It's perfectly harmless," Gird said before she shut him in, giving Phineas a wink. "Catch you later sometime, alright?"

"Yeah," Phineas said. The lid closed and he was plunged into momentary darkness, enough to hear Gird call out "Can I borrow a corset--" before he was transported into a different trunk interior.

Phineas cracked open the lid, finding this trunked wedged onto a shelve with several other pieces of luggage, but with enough room for him to squeeze out. The ploy had worked. As he snuck his way out of the gatehouse, Phineas tried to make sense of all that must have happened during the Welcoming Feast. This was a far different start to the year compared to his previous years of magic schooling.


Ultimately, Phineas could only piece out some of the details of what had transpired during the night of the welcoming feast. Maybe if he got closer to one of the girls, he could get a more direct account. Each of the roommates were rather nice, and had helped him sneak out of their dorm without notice.

So where there was a break after classes, Phineas went to see...
1452.title: Much Ado About Nothing Last Night
